claim: If you swallow gum, nothing will happen to you.

supporting.text: Gum is indigestible and will pass through the digestive system without being broken down, causing no harm.

attacks.text: Gum is indigestible and will pass through the digestive system without being broken down, causing no harm.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require very large quantities to occur.
Some people may experience mild digestive discomfort or nausea after swallowing gum.
Digestive discomfort from gum is usually temporary and not harmful in the long term.

supporting.text: Swallowing gum in small amounts is harmless, as it will be excreted naturally without causing blockages.

attacks.text: Swallowing gum in small amounts is harmless, as it will be excreted naturally without causing blockages.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Even small amounts of gum can accumulate over time and potentially cause blockages if swallowed frequently.
Some individuals may have pre-existing digestive conditions that make even small amounts of gum harmful.

supporting.text: Frequent swallowing of large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, which contradicts the claim.

attacks.text: Frequent swallowing of large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, which contradicts the claim.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require swallowing unrealistically large quantities.
Even rare cases of blockages are medically documented, proving that the risk, though small, exists.
Gum is designed to be indigestible but passes harmlessly through the digestive system in normal amounts.
Design does not guarantee safety; other indigestible items (e.g., coins) also cause blockages in some cases.

supporting.text: Medical consensus states that swallowing gum is generally safe, as it does not stick to the intestines or stomach.

attacks.text: Medical consensus states that swallowing gum is generally safe, as it does not stick to the intestines or stomach.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Cases of intestinal blockage from gum are extremely rare and usually involve swallowing very large quantities over time.
Some individuals may experience mild digestive discomfort or nausea after swallowing gum.
Digestive discomfort from gum is temporary and resolves without medical intervention.

supporting.text: Gum does not dissolve in stomach acid, but it does not cause any adverse effects when swallowed in moderation.

attacks.text: Gum does not dissolve in stomach acid, but it does not cause any adverse effects when swallowed in moderation.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and typically require swallowing very large quantities over a short period.
Some individuals may experience mild digestive discomfort or nausea after swallowing gum.
Digestive discomfort from gum is usually temporary and not medically significant.

supporting.text: While gum is not digested, it poses no health risks unless swallowed in excessive quantities over a short period.

attacks.text: While gum is not digested, it poses no health risks unless swallowed in excessive quantities over a short period.
Swallowed gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children, even in small quantities.
Cases of intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and usually involve pre-existing digestive issues.
Gum may contain artificial sweeteners or other additives that can cause adverse reactions in some individuals.
The additives in gum are generally recognized as safe by health authorities when consumed in typical amounts.
